clinical_study.brief_title: Does Oral Intake Decreases Postoperative Pain Score in Children
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Oral Intake on Pain Score in Children Undergoing Herniorrhaphy

oversight_info.authority: Japan: Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare

brief_summary.textblock:
Pain score after inguinal hernia repair surgery in children decreased as time passed in previous studies. Postoperative oral intake is usually resumed two hours after minor surgery in most of institutions, that may influence children's behavior and pain score.
A recent study suggest that oral intake one hour after minor surgery does not increase the incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting.
The investigators primary endpoint is to clarify whether postoperative oral intake influences postoperative pain score in children.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: whether oral intake influences postoperative pain score in children
primary_outcome.description: pain degree is assessed using mCHEOPS and FLACC in young children, and using FPS-R in older (8 years or older) children

secondary_outcome.description: all children have to stay in hospital for 3 hours, and then, doctors visit the child and decide to discharge or not. Therefore, most of children stay in hospital approximately for 4 hours.

arm_group.description: the investigators permit the patients to resume oral intake two hours after surgery and observe child's behavior and score; cry, facial expression, verbal expression, torso, legs, activity, and consolability

the investigators permit the patients to resume oral intake one hour after surgery and observe child's behavior and score; cry, facial expression, verbal expression, torso, legs, activity, and consolability

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 month to 12 years old children undergoing elective unilateral inguinal hernia repair surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- neurological disease, developmental delay
